parts.instructions: You are going to read a magazine article about an artist who paints flowers. For questions 8-14, choose the answer (A, B, C or D) which you think fits best according to the text.

passage.title: An eye for detail
passage.content:
Artist Carmen Rodriguez, sixty-five, says the gradual decaying process is also part of the fascination for her. With tulips, for example, you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for perhaps a day and they each form themselves into different shapes. They open out and are fantastic. When you first put them in a vase, you think they are boring, but they change all the time with twists and turns.

Carmen has always been interested in plants. 'I did botany at school and used to collect wild flowers from all around the countryside.' In the garden, she wasn't much interested in gardening then; 'I thought they were artificial looking. I only really liked ones that were wild.' Nowadays, the garden owes its beauty to imported plants that originated in far-off lands, though they seem as much at home in her garden as they did in China or the Himalayas. She has a come-what-may attitude to the garden, rather like an affectionate aunt who is quite happy for children to play about undisciplined as long as they don't do any serious damage.

With two forthcoming exhibitions to prepare for, and a ready supply of subject material at her back door, finding time to paint is never a problem for Carmen recently. She now employs an extra gardener, but admits she needs to paint, she knows that, to maintain her connection with her subject matter, you have to get your hands dirty.

Her busiest time of year is spring and early summer, when the tulips are out followed by the poppies. 'They all come out together, and you're so busy' she says. 'I take one flower out and paint it which is how I like to work, and then bring in another one and build up the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish.'

Carmen prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants rather than on the garden as a whole, though she will occasionally paint a group of plants when positioned so as to provide the best viewing angle for the artist. She also inherited the gardener, Diego. 'In fact, I was really not interested in gardening.' We got on very well at first but he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' to some of the things I wanted to put in, but when I said I wanted to plant them, he recognized what I had in mind.

questions.text: In the first paragraph, what fascinates Carmen about flowers?
options: A) Their bright colors and perfect shapes.
B) Their ability to stay fresh for weeks.
C) The way they gradually change and decay.
D) Their resistance to different weather.

questions.text: What does Carmen say about her early interest in plants?
options: A) She preferred cultivated garden flowers.
B) She was only interested in wild plants.
C) She studied plant biology professionally.
D) She collected rare exotic species.

questions.text: What does Carmen say about Diego?
options: A) He felt she was interfering in his work.
B) He immediately understood her feelings.
C) He was recommended by the previous owners.
D) He was slow to see the point of some of her ideas.

questions.text: What is Carmen's approach to painting?
options: A) She will wait until a flower is ready to be picked before painting it.
B) She likes to do research on a plant before she paints it.
C) She spends all day painting an individual flower.
D) She creates her paintings in several stages.
A) are more colorful and better shaped than other flowers.
B) are not easy to paint because they change so quickly.
C) look best some time after they have been cut.
D) should be kept in the house for as long as possible.

questions.text: How does the writer describe Carmen's attitude to her garden?
options: A) She thinks children should be allowed to enjoy it.
B) She prefers planting wild flowers from overseas.
C) She likes a certain amount of disorder.
D) She dislikes criticism of her planting methods.

questions.text: What can be inferred about Carmen's artistic process?
options: A) She works quickly to capture flowers at their peak.
B) She prefers to paint multiple flowers simultaneously.
C) She takes time to develop her paintings gradually.
D) She only paints flowers that are perfectly fresh.

parts.instructions: You are going to read a magazine article about swimming with dolphins. Seven paragraphs have been removed from the article. Choose from the paragraphs A-H the one which fits each gap (15-21). There is one extra paragraph which you do not need to use.

passage.title: Dolphins in the Bay of Plenty
passage.content:
Swimming with groups of dolphins, known as 'pods', is becoming a popular holiday activity for the adventurous tourist. Our travel correspondent reports.

'You must remember that these dolphins are wild. They are not fed or caged in any way. These encounters are purely on the dolphins' terms.' So said one of our guides, as we boarded the boat before we set out for our rendezvous.

[15]

No skill is required to swim with dolphins, just enthusiasm. But we are warned that due to sea conditions, not all trips result in close encounters with the animals. Once on board the boat we sailed for about forty-five minutes, unsure of what we could expect from our trip.

[16]

About half an hour later we had our first sighting: a grey fin breaking the surface, followed by the distinctive arched back and long pointed nose, as we circled the area of sea where they were playing. In a few minutes we could see a dozen or more dolphins, and we prepared for our first encounter with several of them, though only the best swimmers among us could hope to get a close experience.

[17]

Soon we were in the middle of a much larger pod, with dolphins all around us. The first group of six or seven dolphins had drawn us in close, then more swam alongside the boat, racing and overtaking us until they could surf on the boat's bow wave.

[18]

Actually visibility was not at its best, but we had the extraordinary experience of hearing the dolphins' clicking sounds and high-pitched squeaks. The dolphins did not really seem to tire of our presence in the water; they seemed to be genuinely socializing with us rather than just investigating something unusual.

[19]

They had finally finished feeding and were content to play alongside the boat as we made our way slowly back toward shore. Soon most of us had spent at least a few magical seconds in the sea with them. We watched as hundreds of seabirds wheeled through the distance.

[20]

The guides are beginning to recognize some of the local dolphins by the markings on their backs, and some individuals appear time after time. These encounters help scientists better understand dolphin behavior and migration patterns.

[21]

For most people, though, the experience is simply a fun day out that can lead to a deeper appreciation for marine life and ocean conservation.

paragraphs.text: I spent a couple of hours on the boat watching as the surface of the sea was transformed, filled with their perfectly arched dolphin backs. Some of the more advanced swimmers were able to dive down with these dolphins, an experience they clearly enjoyed.

In fact, they are very sociable animals, always supporting each other within the pod. The guides are beginning to recognize some of the local dolphins by the markings on their backs, and some individuals appear time after time.
A spotter plane circled above the bay, looking for large groups of dolphins close to the surface of the water.
These include mothers gently guiding their young alongside, either to introduce them to the boat, or to proudly show off their babies. Yet, when they become bored with playing, they simply leave.
After 20 minutes, we sighted our first small pod. The dolphins came rushing towards the boat, swimming alongside and overtaking us until they could surf on the boat's bow wave.
Eventually it was time to leave, and the boat headed back to our starting point. We picked up another pod, which was joined by more and more dolphins until we had a large group escort.

However, touching the creatures is strongly discouraged. This is despite the fact that dolphins have a very friendly reputation, and have never been known to be aggressive towards human beings in the wild.
This was a magical experience and since time in the water is limited, everyone rotates to get an equal share. We spent the next two hours getting in and out of the boat, and visiting other pods.

parts.instructions: You are going to read about five people who have made significant career changes. For questions 22-28, choose from the people (A-E). The people may be chosen more than once.

people.name: Sarah Chen - Former Lawyer, Now Chef
people.text: I spent twelve years in corporate law before I realized I was completely burned out. The long hours and constant pressure were affecting my health and relationships. I'd always loved cooking and entertaining friends, so I decided to pursue culinary arts. It meant taking a huge pay cut and starting over at age thirty-five, but I've never been happier. The creativity and immediate satisfaction of cooking are completely different from legal work. I had to take out loans to attend culinary school, but it was worth every penny. Now I run my own restaurant and love the direct connection with customers who enjoy my food.

people.name: David Rodriguez - Former Teacher, Now Software Developer
people.text: Teaching was rewarding, but I felt limited by budget constraints and bureaucracy. I was always interested in technology, so I started learning programming in my spare time. The transition took two years of intensive study while still teaching full-time. My previous experience managing classrooms actually helped with project management skills. The salary increase was significant, and I love the problem-solving aspect of coding. I can still educate people, just in a different way now through technology training.

people.name: Maria Santos - Former Accountant, Now Photographer
people.text: Numbers were my life for fifteen years, but I felt creatively stifled. Photography had been a hobby since college, but I never thought I could make a living from it. The transition was gradual - I started taking weekend wedding jobs while keeping my accounting position. Eventually, my photography income matched my accounting salary, so I made the switch. The irregular income was challenging at first, but the artistic satisfaction makes up for the financial uncertainty.

people.name: James Kim - Former Engineer, Now Counselor
people.text: Engineering provided financial stability, but I felt disconnected from meaningful human interaction. I'd always been the person friends came to for advice, so I decided to pursue psychology. It required going back to university for four years while working part-time. The emotional demands of counseling are intense, but helping people work through their problems is incredibly fulfilling. My analytical background actually helps me approach therapy systematically.

people.name: Lisa Martinez - Former Marketing Manager, Now Yoga Instructor
people.text: Corporate marketing felt empty after years of promoting products I didn't believe in. Yoga had helped me through a difficult period in my life, and I wanted to share that healing with others. I spent six months getting certified while still working, then gradually built up a client base. The income drop was dramatic initially, but my quality of life improved immensely. I invested my savings in opening a small studio, which was a big financial risk. Now I wake up excited about my work every day.
